description: A widget that displays a stack of [pages](Page) with a toolbar that allows to navigate back. The toolbar also displays the current page's title and the highest priority [actions](Action) that are added to the NavigationView. Only children of type `Page`, `Action` and `SearchAction` are supported. Since the NavigationView does not compute its own size, the width and height must be defined by the respective layout properties (e.g. either `width` or `left` and `right` must be specified).

parameters.name: properties
parameters.description: Sets all key-value pairs in the properties object as widget properties.

drawerActionVisible.description: Whether to display the so-called "Burger menu" to open the drawer.

toolbarColor.description: The background color of the toolbar.

toolbarHeight.description: The height of the toolbar. Is 0 if not visible.
toolbarHeight.changeEventDescription: Fired when the height of the toolbar changes, e.g. if it changes visibility.

titleTextColor.description: The text color used for page titles.

actionColor.description: The color used for action icons.

actionTextColor.description: The color used for action texts. Only applied on Android, IOS uses the `actionColor` to colorize the action text.

pageAnimation.description: Controls what animation to use when animating a page transition.

navigationAction.description: Action that replaces back button and arrow. When it is replaced the developer is responsible for providing a way to go back on the page stack. Setting the action to null restores back button and arrow.

parameters.name: selector
parameters.description: A selector expression or a predicate function to filter the results.

pages.description: Returns the ordered list of pages on the page stack, with the bottommost page as the first and the topmost page as the last element. Same as children(), but only returns children that are of type `Page`.

parameters.name: constructor
parameters.description: A class to filter the results.

pages.description: Returns the ordered list of pages on the page stack, with the bottommost page as the first and the topmost page as the last element. Same as children(), but only accepts subclasses of `Page`.
